pros: Great pay! Nice people. Happy working there
cons: None. There are no negatives

pros: Great Pay for someone starting out.
cons: They do not care about your credentials unless you are an RN

pros: Co-workers were amazing and helpful

job_title: Registered Nurse Case Manager in Virginia Beach, VA

job_title: Provider Relations Representative in Richmond, VA

job_title: TELEPHONIC RN CASE MANAGER in Richmond, VA
pros:
New company has tried to improve benefits but still falls short of ones lost prior to buy out.

Better benefits/salary than hospital positions. 

I feel the company does value nurses which is hard to find in health care today.
cons:
Recently switched parent companies (Now Optima Health) with a reduction in benefits. 
Poor communication between staff and management. 
Often don't give any/little direction when implementing new process. 
Hard to find someone to answer employee questions. Send you from one manager to another. Often with little or no response.

job_title: Sales Executive in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Great work workmates. Opportunities for growth.
cons: Processing of requests can be slower as it goes to different levels of management

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Small company Benefits are good
cons: High turnover rate Salaries are low compared to similar organizations

review_title: I’m just trying to survive at this point.
job_title: Provider Relations Specialist in Glen Allen, VA
pros: The people, that’s about the only thing.
cons:
Theres favoritism shown to certain employees letting them get away with certain things that others cannot!

Management feels you should have perfected the knowledge of your job without asking questions.  BUT this cannot be when policies and procedures change almost every other month if not weeks.

Every department has a different answer for the same question.  There are no clear answers.

There’s no motivation, the team literally does nothing together besides update calls.  They lure you to this department pitching to you that it’s one big happy family, and it’s the complete opposite.  There are no words of encouragement or anything. 

The benefits are just ok.

pros: Lots to learn and do
cons: Micromanaging, low salary, no advancement

review_title: Decent company with good people. Not the best compensation.
job_title: Business Analyst Senior in Richmond, VA
pros: My team was a pleasure to work with. However, the teams split several times during the merger process with Sentara Healthcare.
cons: I felt like the merger process with Sentara left employees in the dark at times regarding job roles, team/department restructuring, compensation, etc. Employees from various departments slowly started leaving and accepting jobs at other companies. The people who stayed kept on getting more and more responsibilities thrown at them but the compensation did not follow.

review_title: Not a bad job but really stressful. (make sure to keep boundaries)
job_title: MLTSS Care Specialist III (Non-RN) in Richmond, VA
pros:
-Continuous bonuses throughout the pandemic. 
-competitive salary. ( please note Virgina Premier paid more for my position prior to being acquired by Sentara)
-I am very fortunate to have a good supervisor ( this is not the case for everyone. My supervisor does not micro manage.)
-Work from home ability.
-Tuition reimbursement.
cons:
-Very stressful due to case load sizes. (personal opinion)
-ineffective systems in place creating for duplicate work.
-lack of transparency with job salary even within your own position. (I'm not permitted to know how much the salary range is for my current job.)
-work load continues to increase with unrealistic expectations.
-continued issues with communication throughout company.
-* leadership has no idea what Care Specialists do during the day which is root cause of unrealistic policy creation. They seem to have no gauge on how much one person can really handle.

Great Benefits

cons: Leadership has no clue of what they are doing. Individuals are placed in positions based on relationships and not knowledge and experience.

job_title: Provider Services Representative in Richmond, VA

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Awesome benefits, great work enviornment, manageable case loads, work from home options, very flexible.
cons: None, great place to work, supervisors helpful and supportive.

pros: people, schedule, benefits,convenience to restaurants

pros: Fair pay and good work environment
cons: No cons great place to work

pros: Mission and Culture, Work Life Balance
cons: Being owned by a Health System and alignment on values and cultures

pros: they allow new mothers and fathers to bring their child to work for the first 8 months; kudos for that
cons:
Virginia Premier is the most scatter-brained company I have ever worked for. They have a vision but no idea how to execute it; especially at the executive level. The management team doesn't know how to say no to any initiative or prioritize. The departments don't have a set budget. Instead everything is a "must do". The managers and senior workers are drowning in projects and go from project meeting to project meeting and nothing gets done. Much of their revenue is derived from one source (Medallion 4.0) which is dependent on stay on the good graces of the government.

Their processes are wildly inefficient and to make up for this, they carry a workforce that is way too big. They do a disturbing amount of work manually because the systems don't do what they are supposed to. It was also my observation that most positions paid about 15% less than other surrounding companies. I have never been so happy to leave a company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Work from home, good benefits, awesome peers/coworkers
cons: Please look closely at your management staff especially on the 3rd floor of the Richmond location. The most unprofessional, toxic group I’d ever worked for. They have no leadership skills or management skills. Just because someone is a nurse does not qualify them to manage. Stop promoting based on friendships.  The manager has no ability to manage and does not even know what some workers do, They micromanage, treat people as if they are beneath them (unless you are their friend) . You have to constantly watch your back. The satellite offices work so well together but the one in Glen Allen is where your problems lie.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros: Good benefits, nice people, low stress, little responsibility, okay salary, get yearly raise regardless of performance.
cons: Micro management, no ownership of job, not valued, no promotions available, communication stops at management, old school management style. Work product gets passed up with no credit, everything is tasked oriented, with no opportunity to initiate change or projects, no input decision making. Nepotism is rampant...if you know someone, under the age of 30, and know how th play the game, and of you have zero experience in the industry or in management you may be very successful with this company. It doesn't matter how much experience or skills you have it will not be utilized here.

review_title: Was a great place....Now Awful Management
pros: This used to be a great place to work with flexible work life balance. The only benefit now is Working from home.
cons: There are way too many meetings. It’s not possible to be productive when there’s 5 meetings a day. Most of the best, encouraging managers have left. Lately most of the Managers/directors here are incompetent and take no accountability. I can see why the company went downhill - the overall attitude tends to be push the work to someone else. This attitude comes from the directors and radiates onward. I can barely do my job because I’m constantly interrupted by my manager because she can’t read emails, read documents, follow IT instructions, or read a spreadsheet. I don’t understand how someone who can’t seem to read emails is allowed to be a manager.

review_title: Decent place to start a career
pros:
- My team is awesome- both managers and coworkers.
- Benefits are pretty good. 
- If you have a strong work ethic, flexibility, and the ability to do your job well- it is possible to move up quickly. However, you also have to have at least minimal ability to network within the company. I don't disagree with previous reviewers with how promotions are handled, but just being good at your job won't get you ahead in anywhere (well, anywhere worth it). I found that those doing well are good at thier jobs AND have actively worked to develop a strong rapport with everyone in thier department.
cons:
- Exempt salaried employees have to clock in/out... terrible policy.
- The pay. So sad. The strong benefit package helps...but come on. You can go get a job at any other similar company locally and make 25% more with work from home flexibility AND less work.
- Unwilling to implement any true change.

review_title: Incompetence and disrespect are key values
pros: Free parking, holiday time off
cons: Most of senior management got to their roles through favoritism and just “being there the longest.”  The CEO and COO have no clear sense of the direction for the company as they continue to feed into the nepotism and rampant incompetence among leadership.  In the six years I worked here we had 2 employee appreciation “events” both of which were mediocre lunches.   The company continues to lose subject matter experts but acts like there is no turnover issue.  Management will make false promises about promotions and rewards but you will be lucky to even get a thank you.

review_title: I enjoyed coming to work every day.
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: My boss gave me interesting things to do, was clear about his expectations and priorities, and let me decide how best to do my work without micromanagement. I couldn't ask for more. In contrast to some companies I've worked at, VPHP had no issue with investing in the tools (software licenses) needed for us to do our jobs efficiently. I left due to personal circumstances unrelated to the company, and am very grateful I had the chance to work there. Although I didn't have the chance to take advantage of it, I believe VPHP has a generous tuition reimbursement program, and in general education is a strong value of the company.
cons: The 401k isn't available until you've worked for a year, and the health insurance is delayed for a month or so. When I was there, working remotely was not permitted, apparently due to HIPAA requirements.

pros: These are fun people to work with. It is a good entry-level position for recent college graduates. I would recommend this position for any graduating business majors or liberal arts majors that have some type of quantitative work-related experience. There is plenty of career mobility and opportunity for growth.
cons:
Pay structures are noticeably lacking. I left because I received another offer with significantly higher pay and comparable benefits. 

I would advise STEM majors to pursue other offers. Despite the experience you would get out of this position, you would certainly be selling yourself short and could very easily get higher pay for your background and skill-set elsewhere.

job_title: Complex Care Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: New upper management has made some large changes within the company resulting in positive outcomes. There is flexibility to work from home in many positions. You are able to bring your child to work until the are 8months old (and have a private office area while you have them here). Although there have been many cons listed on this site - things are getting better by leaps and bounds.
cons: A con currently is the technology and the unwillingness of some staff to ensure that technology not only works but is more efficient than before. However, that is also in the works and hopefully will soon be off the con list.

pros: Company cars, work from home for some, infant at work program
cons:
Not what it once use to be. No longer cares about keeping the loyal hard working employees. Too much talking by management and not enough action (specifically from the CEO) only things changing are things that benefit the CEO and the puppets just under her. Favouritism in upper management. 
(James Parrot is no longer the CEO as this site states- and that's when the problems started)

review_title: Great Place to Make a Difference
pros: Welcoming and positive atmosphere.  Great benefits. Opportunity to make a positive difference in people's lives. Many very smart and caring people to work with.
cons: The company is experiencing some growing pains. There are positives and negatives that go with that in any growing company. There is more to do than you can ever get done. On the other hand, there is also a great deal of opportunity to advance and do great work in a transforming and evolving company like this.

pros: benefits, connection to VCU, loyal employees, infant at work program, transportation fleet, employee and dependent tuition assistance, presence throughout the state
cons: poor IT and reporting; faulty equipment; intrusive work from home program; backstabbing culture, inconsistent HR practices and policies; discriminatory practices; absentee CMO who travels more than leads; too many executive leaders than staff; inexperienced leaders who were hired for how well they are liked and not for their knowledge and skill; too many initiatives and no follow up; poor use of Six Sigma methodology and process improvement; too many meetings and not enough time to perform work; limited provider network for LTSS services; poor claims department; bullying tactics; allow DMAS to run all over them without questioning; not enough human resources to support case managers; no loyalty to staff who have been with company through their ups and downs; lack of support for managers, employees can go to HR and not respect their leadership; departments work in siloes

pros: Work-life balance, flexible hours if you're in the right area, average medical benefits (recently severely degraded).
cons: No prioritization or proper planning of initiatives. Departments'  work in silos making collaboration a battle. Very poor resource management, if any. WFH  "policy" is a sham, depends primarily on who your manager is. Promotions are driven by vacancies (due to high attrition) rather than merit. Folks who stick around end up in management positions. They know their people's jobs but lack the management skills.

review_title: Welcome to Office Politics - Extreme Version
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Good Benefits, Inclement Weather policy is nice (got some Snow Days/Late Openings, mostly good people, Fairly generous Vacation & Sick Leave, Paid Parking
cons:
Very office political (way too much CYA and Finger Pointing vs getting the job done)
Micromanaged - All employees including FT Exempt have to punch the time clock every day
Too much irrelevant training instead of job specific targeted training
Work/Life balance - you are expected to be there 40+ hours/week & do not receive compensation if you work from home.
Move people around a lot (3 times in a year) - many times for what seems to be little or no reason at all

pros: I like working from home. Generous vacation and sick time. Workload. Coworkers that are now friends.
cons: Unprofessional managers. Unknown company direction. No accountability for managers.

pros: Vacation and sick time. Monday through Friday
cons: Too many to list really. This was once a great place to work.. not now.  Poor management coupled with incompetency have led to a financial crisis that the company has decided to make the employees help pay with benefits.  Most of us had no part in this situation and yet we are punished for it.  Bullying by managers ( done in a manner that can be blamed elsewhere) is common.  Soo many chiefs and too few workers.  All the good ones who can leave are doing so.  Sure, work here if you enjoy favoritism, backstabbing, incompetency, and padding the egos of corporate.  HR is useless to the average employee .  They get on sites like this and blow sunshine up everyone's rear end so they can have some good employee comments ...RUN!

job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros:
It felt great walking out the door knowing I never had to come back.  I can now highly recommend quitting a job for a better offer.  It feels great.

Actual pros:
-work stays at work (could be a negative, most people only have desktops and literally can't take work home)
-my manager was fairly hands-off, not micromanaging like the rest of the company supposedly is, and was always very patient, even when he would get annoyed with a dumb coworker and vent later.  Really I'd be giving this place a 1 if it hadn't been for him.
cons:
- 0 investment in its employees
  - no natural way to develop relationships in the company
    - even in teams, people rarely even went as far as "How was your weekend?"
    - only on my last day did anyone say, "let's go to a happy hour."  I learned more about my teammates, company, management, etc in that one evening than I had since orientation
  - managers don't seem to know good management or meeting practices
  - their "Prime 100" training program was never mentioned after orientation day
    -speaking of Prime 100, WHY.  Why did everyone get a 400-page printout of the online training material???
  - other HR development 'milestones' were never mentioned after day 1
  - HR in general seems more ignored than it usually is
- long-term employees have a clique
-most meetings go like this: I printed off some data. Let's stare at the chart until someone notices something interesting about it.  -_-
-not possible to work from home for most employees (could be a positive on snow days)
-clocking in and out as a salaried employee (though my team didn't really care, I never tested the 80h per 2week requirement)
-poor data quality
-noncompetitive compensation

job_title: Medical Management in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Steady M-F, Work from home. PTO and sick pay.
cons: At the moment everything.  When i first started i could tell the company cared about its employees, I’d recommend that company to anyone. Not anymore. I’d even go as far to say they don’t even really care about their members. You have an HR department that doesn’t do it’s job, they only work to cover the companies behind. This HR is the worst I’ve ever seen, they truly pretend to care with a passion. You have people coming to you with concerns and pretend to take care of it but only push it under the rug. You don’t have the right people working here, and it shows. This company is all about favoritism and backstabbing. There are tons of employees here that break their backs here, only to get run over in the end.  You chose a company to pay out attendants for the care of OUR MEMBERS, who have gone months without getting paid and that issue has been going on for months even years. I’d really like you all to take calls from members every day some even crying because they about to lose their attandent because they can’t get paid and they can’t afford to pay them out of their own pockets. You bring in people for C suite positions who have no interaction with their employees. They change like the weather. You change up the program ever couple of weeks. You hand out things that need to be done on Friday and give out deadlines that aren’t realistic and then get mad that they aren’t finished. Poop travels down at VPHP and that is every week.  You don’t have enough Care Coordinators to do the job it takes to keep up with our member, and HALF or more of Care Coordinators you do have don’t do their job. Don’t answer calls from member who have been calling for weeks to speak to them. So the MCS team has to pick up ALL the slack of the CARE Coordinators. You don’t hold people accountable. You fire people over the smallest of things but have the audacity to keep horrible supervisors, racist employees and more. who have been complained on by multiple people. Also you have openings for positions in house and management has already picked who they wanted before the interviews start, you have recommendations from supervisors holding people back because of personal vendettas. HR should already know about that. I could go on but I’d be here all day.

review_title: I actually enjoy coming to work every day
pros: I like my coworkers and department. My manager is good at her job and doesn't micromanage me or any of the other mangers. Benefits are great and I've learned to like the downtown location. A decent emphasis is put on training.
cons: Anything I dislike here is something you would find at any company. Some people show favoritism (this will always be a thing), some people just aren't that good at their jobs (again, this happens) and sometimes I just don't feel like coming to work. The pay could also be better.

review_title: Good benefits, okay culture, mediocre pay, bad habits but positive!
pros: Great company: Good benefits, okay culture, mediocre pay, bad habits but still positive about the company. I came in wanting to learn and I was able to do that from the beginning working in Finance. Opportunity to do additional projects and branch out if you want work and hard work will eventually get noticed.
cons:
I enjoy working at VAPremier but it's time for some changes. The pay is mediocre compared to other companies. Yes, VAPremier is non-profit but VCUHealth needs to fund the salaries better. A business analyst with the technical knowledge is highly marketable. VAPremier does an amazing job having the opportunity for Business Analysts to learn needed technical skills but if it doesn't pay their analysts the market rate then they will (and do) go off to other companies earning much more. Company needs a kick in the butt culture change. It's somewhat laid back now but it really needs to change the clocking in system (salary and I have to clock in by finger, really?) and the ability to work from home. Many co-workers work more than 40 hours not including commute and they aren't allowed to work from home - honestly, as long as the work is done let people at least work 2 days at home...most people are just sitting around anyways...if they want to be lazy they will be lazy on the clock no matter what. 

Get rid of analysts who refuse to learn. This is mainly for older analysts but some younger ones also are here just for the paycheck. There are a lot of people who would do well from an opportunity from VAPremier to work in the finance department but the positions are held up by those who do not care about their work and refuse to learn. 

Pay your employees better! It is very disheartening to see very talented and skilled analysts not make as much money as their peers when it's clearly obvious where the talent is + it's VERY obvious when a "senior" analyst constantly asks questions of lower tier analysts b/c they have no clue how to run a simple query or weren't paying attention during a meeting.

job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Benefits, casual office environment, and three weeks paid vacation time. Hours aren't too bad but sometime a good chance you will work more than 40 hours
cons: Poorly managed, no training, low pay, and overall low morale among the employees. Even managmen looks like they are miserable. Being a non-profit, everyone is under paid so no one seems happy and it's a downward spiral from there

pros: Bring your baby to work, enjoy my co-workers, and serving those that are less fortunate.
cons: Oh where to start! The projects that lack vision - it’s like one project after the next without closing the previous projects before we’re off to the next. The staff is stretched thin.  There is no real training, and the unprofessional HR staff that doesn’t know how to lead or provide assistance - they lead by bullying people and talking down to people.

pros: Work From Home that's about it.
cons:
Nepotism
Nepotism is the granting of jobs to one's relatives or friends in various fields, including business, politics, entertainment, sports, religion and other activities. Nepotism is the act of using one's power to secure better jobs or unfair advantages for a family member when they may not have the right skill, experience or motivation compared to others. The term originated with the assignment of nephews to important positions by Catholic popes and bishops. Instances of business executives expediently hiring their children to their firms, is a modern-day example of nepotism in practice. This is trough out the company..

pros: PAY higher than competitors rates
cons: Disorganized, favoritism, antiquated charting systems, inaccessible management - too thick in mid-upper management while not hiring enough staff to handle members

pros: Good place to start in the industry as they try to invest in the growth of their employees. Strong mission to care for the undeserved.
cons: Employee training is not well put together by HR.  Some senior level managers are doing just enough to get by.  Does not allow work from home which would improve work life balance.

review_title: Many people didn't like working here, maybe you will...
pros:
*Paid parking
*Good Health benefits
*Some flexibility
*Company paid time off (inclement weather, power outages, etc)
*Refreshments provided (coffee, tea, etc....)
*Yearly 3% cost of living raise
*Casual wear on Fridays and also during specific times of the years (Jeans)
cons:
I liked working at Virginia Premier in the beginning, however, I started to dislike it very quickly within 2 months of working there. The work was too scattered without any structure. You are worked tirelessly with 
low pay, while Managers and VP's of course, get to enjoy a comfortable living wage while most of the 'lower level positions' work at an hourly rate that does not allow an individual to feel like they are really 'making it.'  The majority of the employees are unprofessional, and I did not enjoy interacting with most of them. Some of the employees need to take a class on professionalism and communication, as some people ask or talk about things without any tact or consideration. Also, a lot of the people there are very incompetent and demonstrate poor communication skills, as well as common sense. There were some people however, who were very friendly and could at least acknowledge you if you spoke to them. 

There were constant office moves with employees, and unnecessary changes around the company that costs a slew of money; that could have been going towards incentive based raises. Although, there is a 3% cost of living raise every year, that would only allow you to 'get by'.  Although there were opportunities to move on to other departments, people only did so to make more money. However, most wound up quitting as they didn't like the demand on the work or the working environment. The building is old, unsanitary, and not pleasant to work in.  

I would definitely not consider working here again, or would recommend anyone to work here. You might like it depending on what department you work in, or if the company has changed thereafter reading these reviews.  Also, if you like to work independently, this will not be the company for you. Most of the cons that I've stated here will be at nearly almost every job, however, there is something in the air at Virginia Premier that really made me and others not want to be there.

*CONSISTENTLY HIGH turnover rate
*Poor work culture
*Unprofessional work environment
*No structure around job duties
*Incompetent Management/Employees
*LOW PAY/No overtime/No incentive based raises
*Unsanitary working environment (nasty bathrooms, all sorts of bugs, offices never cleaned properly)
*Micromanagement
*Constant seat movement (you will never sit in your same seat one time for more than 1 year or maybe six months, be prepared to live out of a box)
*Unhappy people (due to the demand on work, low pay, lack of job satisfaction)
*The area
*Too many levels of Management and VP's

review_title: Company that is going in the wrong direction! Miserable workforce!
pros:
Good annual and sick leave
paid parking
cons:
Culture of finger pointing and CYA
Lack of communication
Sr. Leadership out of touch with staff and disregard volume of work and endless shifting of priorities. Mentality is one of just get it done even if Leadership changes priorities every other day!
Favoritism totally out of control!!
Organization that lacks leadership and consistency regarding practices and treatment of staff

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Excellent pay, benefits,holidays and coworkers.  Annual raises.  Lots of activities for employee participation, picnic, holiday party, etc.  Nice facilities. OK place to work.
cons: Totally unprepared for the new initiatives from DMAS.  Minimal training on new programs.  No support for managers.  Majority of upper level management have left or have been fired.

pros: Virginia Premier has good benefits
cons: Virginia Premier is growing and I believe the company is taking on more lines of business, and not training employees the adequate training they need to do there job. As an employee working here I don't feel much of value, you don't get the appreciation needed and it since we moved to our new location, it has been burden due to have to spend more money to come to work. I'm an employee and  I am close to being one of those medicaid recipients.  The management is the worst and they are allowed to mistreat and abuse there authority and nothing is done about.

pros: Generous annual and sick leave, good health plan, valuable mission, and dedicated co-workers
cons: Poor management, unhappy workforce, inadequate communication and direction, and lack of appreciation for employees.  Exempt employees are required to clock in/out and micro managed. Lack of genuine feedback and consistency within management.  The company is branching out into new areas without sufficient staff and systems in place.  Current staff is frustrated, under appreciated, and over worked.

pros: There are no pros. If you're smart, educated, competent, and compassionate please run away. They only want dumb yes men to work here. They are threatened by smart people with great ideas.
cons: Everything. Incompetent senior leadership. Top heavy leadership. Micromanaging staff. Racist. No morals, values, or  worth ethics within majority of the employees. I'm shocked they are still allowed to operate

review_title: An easy place to work that could use some outside perspective.
job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros:
Good benefits and a good work life balance for most positions. 

Good job security for most positions.

Encouraging of higher learning such as Master’s programs.
cons:
Salary below market and not a competitive atmosphere. Because of this, underperformance across departments is the norm.

No clear decision making by C-Suite.

job_title: Systems Analyst I in Richmond, VA
pros:
Health insurance discount - if you participate in Wellness program
Paid parking downtown- in Richmond office
401K 
Decent benefits
Have a program where new parents can bring babies to work for several months
cons:
Specific to my sub department:
No flexibility with lunch times
Either feast or famine with work load - either nothing or struggling to keep head above water

job_title: Provider Data Specialist II in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Helping the members across the state of Virginia receive medical care. There used to be a great company culture that made you proud to say you were a part of the organization. Great benefits.
cons: The mission of the company is a mission that I personally stood behind. And with that I took my role at the company very seriously and gave it my all day in and day out. Unfortunately not many worked with a passion and ethic such as I. There were many staff members who were dedicated, and worked hard at their jobs year after year. Unfortunately management across the company was some of the worst I have ever encountered, therefore causing the loss of hard working dedicated employees time and time again. Following proper procedures in dealing with issues with other employees or managers brings little resolution. Faith in managers and HR department is extremely low at best and for good reason.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Professional Growth and Experience, Negative Business Outlook
job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros: Great opportunity for growth, decent salary and benefits, dynamic industry, and good training opportunities.
cons: High turnover rate, lack of cross departmental collaboration and communication, salary is slightly lower than competitors, growing too quickly, and almost no culture.

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Good benefits!  Recognizes accomplishments regularly!  Flexible it's time off!  Holidays and weekends off! Encourage continued education and offered in house for advancement opportunities. Some work from home options!
cons: High management turnover.  Poor communication of new processes and procedures.  Productivity goals not realistic at times!  Doesn't ask staff of suggestions prior to process improvements!

review_title: Hard work, low pay and bad management w/ their head up their butt
job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros: The only Pros that I can think of is the actually Health Benefits and the fact that they have paper plates and plastic utensils in all break rooms. Everything else SUCKS!!
cons: The company is actually going into the wrong direction. Too many worthless meetings, false promises, worthless projects and the pay sucks. There are too many managers that are lost and no room for promotions. Good employees are over looked and bad employees are praised.

pros: Virginia premier is a small but growing company with lost of opportunities to advance. You work with all levels of management and Virginia premier offers training to sharpen your skills
cons: I feel that there should be more telework opportunities. Teleworking is growing more and more common in most companies.

review_title: Unfortunately, the position no longer exists.
pros: This was a company that provided the best equipment for the job. The team members were like family. The benefits were superb. If the transportation department reemerges from the ashes, I'd be first in line.
cons: The pay was not super great for the responsibility entrusted to drivers, but the comradely, holidays and health benefits offset the pay.

pros: Good co workers, support from some parts of management is wonderful.
cons: PLEASE let at least some of your positions work from home. All the other companies do it. Myself and countless other employees have left due to this issue.

review_title: Horrible computer system, tons of stress, terrible outlook
pros:
Room for advancement if you wanted it, but even lower level managers regularly work late and even overnight.
All benefits have decreased significantly recently but are average now.
cons:
Serious stress and long hours if you're on technical side. The new system is awful and creates many problems. Micromanagement and constant finger pointing. No cooperation between departments.
This company is going downhill FAST and I really doubt it'll be in business in a few years. Constant serious problems.

job_title: Business Analyst I in Richmond, VA
pros: Great benefits, wonderful people to work with, paid parking and holidays off.  Overtime available for the hourly on a consistent basis can work longer hours Monday-Friday and also weekends.
cons: Low pay scale. Management in constant meeting throughout the day. Not enough Tiers within departments. Communication between departments and company need to be widen.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros: Very good benefits.  The company cares about it's employees.  The company has an awesome CEO.  The company is making a difference in peoples lives.
cons: Managers are in place who don't have management experience.

job_title: Member Service Representative in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Benefits, hours, people,  affiliated to vcu and can immediate family member can get reduced tuition for members.
cons: Rude clients, inconsistency with training and providing feedback,

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Great co-workers, part of vcu, benefits are decent
cons: Everything. If you are a professional who prides yourself on competency, has experience, and deserves respect, this is not the place for you. Management runs in wolf packs and are disrespectful as well as incompetent. This is the most dysfunctional mess I've ever seen at a company. I'd advise anyone to look elsewhere.

pros: This company has amazing salary and benefits that begin immediately upon hire and accrue...!!!
cons: While SOP were pushed daily, office cliques and politics could make this a minefield to work in.

job_title: LTSS Care Coordinator in Richmond, VA
pros: Family type atmosphere.  Not a huge nationwide company so you get to know most of your co-workers.
cons: Being told different things by management when new programs Roll out that may affect your job and licensure.

pros: Job security, training opportunities, work from home program, bring newborns to work, competititive salary.
cons: Salaried employees have to clock in, many projects going at once, feeling that at times company bites off more than they can chew.

review_title: This is a GREAT place to work
pros: Wonderful employees, great benefits, work life balance
cons: Alot of new employees being hired because of company growth so it may be a little unorganized at times.

job_title: Case Management in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Work from home and bring your baby to work with you
cons: With over 10 years at this company.  I have never seen it like this. Vphp is a big mess. I waiting on the day Dmas and VCU step in. I want to know how these so call Directors and managers get hire.

pros: You don't need to have experience to work there, as you will spend all of your time in pointless meetings and HR mandated training geared toward 12 year olds.
cons: Senior managers tend to hire young, petite, attractive white women to run their teams.  They are often spotted flirting with each other in hallways, offices, and local eateries.  Makes you wonder what else they are doing after hours.

pros: Good team of people. Decent pay.
cons: In two years I got zero reviews or feedback about my performance. Some management has no clue what they are doing. After CEO, Jim Parrot passed away the company has been going downhill fast.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Close to home for me. They let you take your new born to work. Good start out job
cons: Endless calls from rude customers. You hardly have time to take bathrooms breaks

pros: Good people and good opportunities
cons: Too top heavy.  Too many chiefs.

job_title: Member Services Representative II in Richmond, VA
pros:
Benefits are fantastic
In house training is great
People you work with are the most part fair and friendly

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Nothing. Awful, horrible, dirty building, ghetto employees, slaves of MCV health system who doesn't trust anyone in VPHP leadership.
cons: For the manager who just posted the review, you are still lured by this ghetto company. Once you'll work there for 6 months, then you'll be googling job positions like 99% of the people out there. Trash company, awful leadership.

job_title: Manager, Human Resources & OD in Richmond, VA
pros: Great people and great benefits, interview process was very smooth, and I was most impressed with the negotiating process...quick turn around.
cons: I have not worked in position long enough to have any cons.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Richmond, VA
pros: The work is actually interesting and mission focused and it's great that it's in the VCU Health System. Really flexible work schedules.
cons: Horribly mismanaged, layoffs seem impending, a lot of people are jumping ship at the moment. The company also pays significantly under market value for most positions - especially analysts.

review_title: Great at first but highly stressful at the end

pros: High growth, good work life balance

pros: Company invests in its employees and cares about the population it serves.

job_title: Medical Management in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Good benefits.  The pay is above the standard for the market.
cons: Operates out of compliance to state and federal regulations.  Threaten employees job security if they do not do the same.  Even if those actions cost that individual their license.
